title: Chain (algebraic topology)
summary: In algebraic topology, a k-chain is a formal linear combination of the k-cells in a cell complex. In simplicial complexes (respectively, cubical complexes), k-chains are combinations of k-simplices (respectively, k-cubes),[1][2][3] but not necessarily connected. Chains are used in homology; the elements of a homology group are equivalence classes of chains.
